(40) 221stConclusions,Minute 2.)Anti-invasionreconnaissances.Loss of The First Sea Lord reported that the Moharned Ali-el-KebirMohamed AH- (7,527 tons), which had left Avonmouth for Gibraltar on theel-Kebir. 5th August with military and naval details totalling 732, had been torpedoed about 250 miles west of Malin Head. It was believedthat nearly all those on board had been saved.The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.2. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that the tension between this country and Japan had certainly relaxed (seetelegram No. 1849 R from Tokyo).He was considering the release of one or two of the Japanesewhom we had arrested, but, on the whole, he was disposed to waiton events for a day or two longer. Later on, perhaps through themediation of a third party, the dispute might be terminated by theexchange of the remaining prisoners.There was a good deal of evidence that the Japanese intendedto invade French Indo-China. In reply to a question from theAmerican Ambassador in Tokyo, however, Mr. Matsuoka haddisclaimed any such intention.The Foreign Secretary said that he proposed to instruct sir Robert Craigie to put a similar question. The more disclaimerswe had on record against the Japanese, the better.The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.The Baltic 3. On the otherhand, if we granted de facto recognition, we should be taking aweaker line than the United States. Further, Russia might attackFinland again and absorb the whole country. If we had recognisedRussia's absorption of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, it would bedifficult not to recognise her absorption of Finland.The War Cabinet-Deferred a decision as to recognition of the absorption bythe Soviet Union of the Baltic States.Japan.Arrest of Britishsubjects.(previous reference:W.M. The War Cabinet had before them a Report by the Chiefsof Staff (W.P. (40) 309) recommending the retention of the presentban on visitors to towns in the protected areas.The War Cabinet-Approved the Chiefs of Staff recommendations that theban on visitors should not be removed.6. The War Cabinet had before them a Second Report by theChiefs of Staff (W.P. (40) 306).In discussion the following points were made : (i) Generally speaking, the morale of the Allied Contingentsseemed to be improving. The morale of the BelgianContingents, however, was described as "only fair."(ii) A plan was under consideration for sending to Tangiera number of French troops who were unwilling tocontinue to serve against Germany.The War Cabinet took note of the Report by the Chiefsof Staff.Home Defence.Effect on food -production ofmilitary and airpreparations.7. The War Cabinet had before them Memoranda by theMinister of Agriculture and Fisheries and the Secretary of Statefor War (W.P. (G.) (40) 206 and 210).The Minister' of A griculture and Fisheries said that he made no complaint against the orders which had been issued by the WarOffice, and by the Commands. But certain units had not obeyedthose orders, with the result that wanton damage to agriculture hadbeen done. Certain War Office contractors had also been at fault.The Secretary of State for War said that the Governmentwould have failed in their duty if they had not pressed forward at high speed with the construction of defences. The MilitaryAuthorities had been told to observe commonsense, restraint, andcourtesy in their dealings with agriculturists. If instances of abusewere brought to the notice of the Authorities, they would be investigated and, if authenticated, disciplinary action would betaken.It had been decided to consolidate the instructions as to thedirection and planning of all obstructions. A meeting was being held that afternoon at which all the Departments concerned wouldbe represented, for the purpose of reaching agreement on the consolidated instructions. The War Cabinet-(a) Took note that it was hoped that agreement would bereached at the meeting to be held that day onconsolidated instructions as to the direction and planning of all obstructions.(b) Invited the Minister for Aircraft Production to considerthe report of the meeting referred to at (a) and to settle,on behalf of the War Cabinet, any outstanding points in consultation with the Ministers concerned.France. 8. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that the care of French Committee on French Resistance had drawn attention to the refugees in this importance of retaining the goodwill of the different classes of country. Frenchmen now in this country, who would sooner or later bereturning home. Lord Bessborough had been appointed toco-ordinate the welfare work for Frenchmen now in this country,both military and civilian. To enable him to carry out this workhe would need a small staff, to which should be attached one or twoCivil Servants, in order to ensure co-ordination of arrangements between the Departments concerned. Lord Bessborough would keep in close touch with the Committee on French Resistance. TheSecretary of State asked the War Cabinet to approve, in principle,arrangements on these lines.The War Cabinet-Approved in principle the arrangements proposed by theForeign Secretary, and instructed the Secretary to bring them to the notice of the Departments concerned and to invite their co-operation.Sweden. 9. The Prime Minister said that General Wavell had returned to this country and that he would be seeing him that afternoon, in order to discuss with him the position in the middle east.Richmond Terrace, S.W.August 8, 1940.1,
